К МКС стартует американский грузовой космический корабль Cygnus
02 Nov 2019, 00:02 by Gubanoff
К МКС стартует американский грузовой космический корабль CygnusИнтерфакс — Агентство Военных Новостей — информация о военно–политической ситуации в стране, о деятельности Министерства обороны и других силовых министерств, о…www.militarynews.ru
Вашингтон. 2 ноября. ИНТЕРФАКС — Американская ракета–носитель Antares с грузовым космическим кораблем Cygnus в субботу стартует к Международной космической станции (МКС), сообщает Национальное управление США по аэронавтике и исследованию космического пространства (NASA).Запуск намечен на 09:59 по восточному времени США (16:59 мск) с космодрома NASA Уоллопс, который размещается на одноименном острове у атлантического побережья американского штата Вирджиния.По сообщению NASA, погодные условия в районе космодрома на 95% благоприятны для проведения запуска.Стыковка корабля Cygnus с МКС запланирована на 4 ноября. Она будет осуществляться путем захвата сблизившегося со станцией "грузовика" дистанционной рукой–манипулятором станции Canadarm–2 и последующим присоединением его к американскому модулю Unity.Запуск осуществляется в рамках коммерческого контракта NASA с корпорацией Northrop Grumman, которой принадлежит ракета–носитель и автоматический грузовой космический корабль. Cygnus должен будет доставить на МКС около 3,7 тонн груза, в том числе продовольствие, а также оборудование и материалы для проведения десятков научных исследований.Это будет уже 12–й полет космического "грузовика" корпорации Northrop Grumman к МКС. Был также еще один неудачный запуск в 2014 году, когда корабль не долетел до станции вследствие аварии ракеты–носителя Antares. Первый успешный запуск Cygnus состоялся 18 сентября 2013 года.Как сообщалось, накануне от МКС отстыковался японский грузовой космический корабль Японии HTV–8 (Kounotori 8 — "Белый аист 8"). 28 сентября он доставил на станцию более четырех тонн грузов. Корабль находился в составе МКС пять недель. 2 ноября японский "грузовик", загруженный мусором и отходами со станции, будет сведен с орбиты и сгорит в плотных слоях атмосферы Земли.

Towards sustainable diplomacy

02 Nov 2019

Etienne Plamondon Emond Special collaboration
This text is part of a special notebook.
Climate change is an international issue. But some scientific initiatives to respond to it, all over the world, have roots in Quebec. The latest report published by the Global Carbon Project was far from encouraging. While he highlighted a growth in the use of renewable energy, he also noted a 2% increase in CO2 emissions in 2018. Issued annually, this global carbon budget - or Global Carbon Budget - has the merit of give the right time and update more frequently than the documents of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). To achieve this, the Global Carbon Project involves 76 scientists from 57 research institutions in some fifteen countries. And this initiative is led by Future Earth, an even larger network of thousands of researchers, led in part from Montreal.
Launched in 2012 at the Rio + 20 Conference on Sustainable Development in Rio de Janeiro, this international organization for sustainable development research began its activities in 2015. That year, Quebec's metropolis was designated as the one of five hubs to host its global secretariat with Paris, Tokyo, Stockholm and Boulder in Colorado. Amy Luers, Executive Director of Future Earth since 2017, is well-placed in her Guy Street office to understand the importance of science diplomacy. From 2015 to 2016, she worked on climate issues for the White House, then under the leadership of the Obama administration. In November 2015, the American participated in the United States delegation to COP21, which led to the Paris Climate Agreement.
"What I found was that the discussions, collaborations, and connections in the scientific world were very important to building relationships that help move forward," she recalls. Scientists speak a common language, even though they live all over the world. This common motivation to find solutions and understand the challenges brings them together. "
In addition to the five global clusters, Future Earth relies on five regional offices and twenty national networks to carry out some twenty international research projects.
"The 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), adopted at the United Nations in 2015 for the 2030 horizon, constitute a frame of reference from which this network works. These goals range from reducing poverty to tackling climate change to gender equality and access to health. "We are focusing first and foremost on how, with offices in several countries, we can facilitate these collaborations between scientists, policy makers and companies on these different issues," she says. Our role is to ensure that everything is better than the sum of its parts to advance the agendas. "

Montreal color

Future Earth's network, research and efforts are resolutely on a global scale. But Montreal dyes its activities. "When I started, I was very excited by the fact that the executive offices are here," says Amy Luers. Why ? She wanted to launch a reflection in line with an expertise present in the Quebec metropolis: that in artificial intelligence. The Sustainability in the Digital Age initiative was launched in the last year, thanks to funding from the ClimateWorks Foundation, the Fonds de recherche du Québec, the Canadian Institute for Advanced Research and Mitacs. Its goal ? Improve knowledge for cUnderstand how digital tools could help build a more sustainable and equitable world, but also prevent them from amplifying certain abuses, such as resource depletion or social inequalities.
"This is an area in which we have work by global nature," she insists. But we have the roots here to build this leadership in artificial intelligence, and more broadly in digital technology, at the intersection of international issues of community sustainability, biodiversity, climate and water. "
After all, local science can sometimes snowball. The Ouranos consortium is one example. It helps regional or local communities to adapt to climate change. But this does not prevent it from achieving successful international collaborations, especially in terms of modeling, projection and scenario to carry out risk analysis. But since 2014, this research center in climatology has taken several steps to replicate and export its organizational model in other regions of the world. "There are some who say that this is not science anymore, but rather a way of doing things. In my opinion, this is science, says Alain Bourque, General Manager of Ouranos. It's more of social science than physical, but it's potentially more important. "
Financed by departments, municipalities and electricity producers among others, Ouranos responds to the concrete needs of the latter while involving university researchers.
"The very important aspect of our way of working is to strongly involve science users in all project stages, including defining priorities and writing a research proposal," explains Bourque. . Often, they will become scientific partners of the projects. "
The formula has hit the mark, so much so that it attracts foreign eyes. A research platform inspired by this model in the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region in France has even adopted the name of Ouranos. The Quebec consortium conducts formal exchanges with the latter, but also with other organizations elsewhere in the world. In 2017, he received $ 1 million from the Government of Quebec to help the Climate Change Competence Center Morocco (4C Morocco) set up an adaptation platform in this Maghreb country. Ouranos now wants to send an employee to the offices of 4C Morocco to consolidate this partnership.
"To be honest, we are quite curious about the experiences abroad to see how they could influence our model, which we continually seek to improve," says Alain Bourque.
